The Battle of Machnivka was one of the first battles in the Khmelnytsky uprising that was fought near the village of Machnivka in the Bracław Voivodeship of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. and rebellious Cossacks led by Maksym Kryvonis. The battle ended in a Cossack victory with the village being occupied and sacked by the rebels.
Background
In early 1648, the Khmelnytsky Uprising began. In May of 1648, the Cossacks and Tatars decisively defeated the Polish-Lithuanian army at Zhovti Vody and then at Korsuń. These victories were followed by an outbreak of the uprising on the entire territory of modern-day Ukraine, including the Bracław voivodeship, which was almost completely seized by the rebels led by a prominent Cossack leader Maksym Kryvonis in the summer of 1648, who later launched a campaign with goal of capturing Podolia and Volhynia - in June he captured Pavoloch, Berdychiv and Myropil. Makhnivka was a large checkpoint of the Polish army in Podolia, where they could easily organise a defense. At the same time, prince Jeremi Wiśniowiecki found out about the Polish-Lithuanian defeated at Korsun, which forced him to leave Left-Bank Ukraine and move towards Podolia. At the end of June 1648, first Cossack units approached Makhnivka. Khmelnytsky, meanwhile, sent a Cossack regiment led by Ivan Hyria numbering approximately 5 thousand people.
Battle
There are several different versions about events during the battle. According to one source, on 8 of July the Cossacks launched an attack on Makhnivka and besieged the Polish forces inside the castle. The first attempt to capture the castle failed. Meanwhile, Tyszkiewicz, who was at the time in Berdychiv, sent a letter to Wisniowiecki with asking him to help the besieged garrison. The next attempt to seize the castle was successful - the Cossacks managed to capture it with a trick.
Aftermath
The village was sacked in course of the battle and the Polish influence in the Bratslav region was shattered, while Kryvonis continued his campaign and captured Following the battle, Polish Crown Forces left Makhnivka and moved to Starokostiantyniv, where another battle took place.
